pullRequest.body:
Feat: Add `Congruent` in `Topology.MetricSpace.Congruence`

This is a port of:

https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib/pull/18214

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: @jsm28 Here is the first PR from the bunch.  There wasn't any comments from you about this file in the previous PR.  Let me know if there are any modifications that you would like me to make to the port.
Perhaps @JovanGerb has something to say about this definition?

When talking about congruent or similar triangles, it's really important to distinguish triangle ABC from triangle ACB (the two are congruent only if the triangle is isosceles). I'm confident that indexed families are correct for defining congruences, and sets would not be correct.

There are (at least) two notions that are equivalent in a Euclidean space:

- the one introduced in this PR, `∀ i j, edist (f i) (f j) = edist (g i) (g j)`
- `∃ e : X ≃ᵢ Y, e ∘ f = g`

I don't know which one is called "congruent" in general case.

There was a long discussion in the thread https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/217875-Is-there-code-for-X.3F/topic/Euclidean.20Geometry about the merits of the two approaches for defining congruence (equal pairwise distances versus existence of an isometric equivalence). Some evidence was found in that thread that the more general notion (equal pairwise distances) is indeed used in the literature between different metric spaces that don't have an isometric equivalence.

In any case, once things move from the general setup in metric spaces to more specific Euclidean applications, the fact that equal distances implies an isometric equivalence in Euclidean spaces with the same finite dimension (or various other such Euclidean cases) will be a natural result to prove early on (that thread has some discussion of how `inner_weightedVSub` / `dist_affineCombination` might be used to prove such results).
IMHO, this should be discussed in the docstring.

> IMHO, this should be discussed in the docstring.

Doc-string updated.

```suggestion
def Congruent (v₁ : ι → P₁) (v₂ : ι → P₂) [PseudoEMetricSpace P₁]
```
Does it mean that we can't deal with congruence and category theory at the same time?
I don't know as I haven't done much with category theory in mathlib.  Maybe @jsm28 knows?

I have no idea what the effects of this notation would be on using congruence together with category theory. (I do expect to have a use for category theory in *combinatorial* geometry - it's how mathlib handles compactness arguments - though probably not for congruence of families of points in that combinatorial geometry.)
This does not match the implementation that uses indexed families of points.
Please remove the unneeded parentheses that make the definition harder to read.

```suggestion
    Congruent v₁ v₂ ↔ ∀ i₁ i₂ : ι, edist (v₁ i₁) (v₁ i₂) = edist (v₂ i₁) (v₂ i₂) :=
  Iff.rfl
```
Please review every line you wrote to remove obfuscation parentheses. Also search and replace all your `fun … => …` to `fun … ↦ …`.
Are you aware of the `peel` tactic? I’m not saying you must use it instead of `forall₂_congr` but in more complicated cases it is a lot easier than wrestling those lemmas.
Here you can probably use `exact_mod_cast h hn`. Again this is not a request for change, only information for you.

```suggestion
    simp only [dist_nndist] at h
    exact_mod_cast h hn)
```
You can use dot notation here.
This definition has nothing to do with congruences, right?

```suggestion
  ext
```

```suggestion
  funext <| map_comp_apply h
```
Why not using the Congruent namespace? This would allow a lot more dot notation, right?
Please merge all those `rw`.

pullRequest.title: feat(Topology/MetricSpace/Congruence): define Congruent
